title: Apology Languages
description: Explore how you apologize and what makes apologies meaningful to you.

questions.text: When I need to apologize, I tend to...
choices: Say 'I'm sorry' and explain what I did wrong
Focus on making things right with actions
Express how bad I feel about hurting them
Ask what I can do to make it better

therapeutic.rationale: Apology styles vary like love languages. Verbal-apologizers use words; action-takers make amends; feeling-expressers show remorse; askers seek input. The apology that works for you may not work for your partner.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different apology styles may miss each other. The action-taker's partner may want words; the verbal-apologizer's partner may want changed behavior. Learn what your partner needs.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared apology style makes apologies feel natural and effective.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you typically apologize? Does it seem to work for your partner?

questions.text: An apology feels meaningful to me when it includes...
choices: Acknowledgment of what they did and its impact
Genuine remorse—not just words
A commitment to change or not repeat it
All of these—real apologies are complete

therapeutic.rationale: Meaningful apology components vary. Acknowledgment validates; remorse shows care; commitment gives hope; complete-needers want all three. Knowing what your partner needs helps you apologize effectively.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different needs require different apologies. Learn which component matters most to your partner.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared apology needs create aligned expectations about what counts as a real apology.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What makes an apology feel meaningful to you? What's missing when apologies fall flat?

questions.text: The hardest part of apologizing for me is...
choices: Admitting I was wrong
Knowing what to say
Feeling vulnerable
Apologizing doesn't feel that hard to me

therapeutic.rationale: Apology barriers prevent repair. Admitting-wrong struggles involve ego; not-knowing is skill; vulnerability is exposure; easy-apologizers have lower barriers. Understanding your barrier helps you overcome it.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different barriers need different support. The vulnerability-struggler may need safety; the not-knower may need scripts.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared barriers create mutual understanding about why apologies are hard.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What makes apologizing hard for you? What would make it easier?

questions.text: After my partner apologizes, I usually...
choices: Accept it and move forward
Need some time before I fully feel better
Want to talk through what happened
Depend on how sincere it feels

therapeutic.rationale: Post-apology responses vary. Quick-movers process fast; time-needers process slow; talkers need discussion; sincerity-readers evaluate. How you receive apologies affects whether your partner feels safe apologizing.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different responses need acknowledgment. The quick-mover may feel their slow partner holds grudges; the time-needer may feel rushed. Honor each other's pace.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared response creates aligned expectations about post-apology recovery.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What do you need after your partner apologizes? Does that happen?

questions.text: I believe apologies in relationships should...
choices: Happen when someone does something hurtful
Focus on impact, not just intent
Include changed behavior, not just words
Be given freely without keeping score

therapeutic.rationale: Apology beliefs shape expectations. Hurt-based believers apologize for harm; impact-focusers own effect regardless of intent; behavior-changers value action; score-avoiders give freely. Aligned beliefs prevent resentment about apologies.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different beliefs may cause frustration. The impact-focuser may want apologies the intent-focuser doesn't think are needed. Discuss your beliefs.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared beliefs create aligned expectations about when and how apologies happen.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What are your beliefs about apologies in relationships? Where did those come from?
